The meaning of the eight kinds of speech (7) The meaning of the eight kinds of speech refers to saying what one has seen, heard, cognized, or known, and saying what one has not seen, not heard, not cognized, or not known.

Second, distinguishing according to the objects.

This is called hearing.
Therefore the treatise says:

Regarding objects that are not seen or heard,
Based on previous seeing and hearing,
One uses inference to know them and calls it knowing.
Therefore the treatise says:
The knowing mind is the subsequent cognition of the previous three minds.
The subsequent discriminating mind is called realization.
What is discrimination?
First, having seen, one later contemplates and gives rise to the thought of seeing.
Or, forgetting the previous seeing, one gives rise to the thought of not seeing.
This is the realization after seeing.
The realization after hearing and knowing can be understood in the same way.
However, this mind of realization
is not only produced after the three minds of seeing, hearing, and knowing.
It is also born after not seeing, not hearing, and not knowing.
For example, first not seeing,
later forgetting not seeing, giving rise to the thought of seeing.
This is the realization after not seeing. The realization after not hearing and not knowing is the same.
This is the second aspect of distinguishing based on objects.
Third, based on the four minds, distinguishing according to meaning.
The mind of consciousness is called seeing,
because it obtains the present object.
The mind of thought is called hearing,
because the object is not present.
Moreover, the mind of thought knows provisional names,
so it is called hearing.
The receiving mind is called cognition.
Because it cognizes what is contrary or agreeable.
The acting mind is called knowledge.
Because it strongly discriminates.
The four minds are like this.
Next, it clarifies the different ways of expressing oneself through seeing and so forth.
The essentials are briefly only eight.
If expanded, there are many.
What are the expanded characteristics?
If according to the Abhidharma teachings,
there are thirty-two different ways of expressing oneself through seeing and so forth.

sixteen are incorrect speech.

Hearing, sensing, and knowing are also like this.
This immediately becomes four.

they answer,
I have not seen.
The same applies to hearing, perceiving, and knowing.
It is further divided into four.
Together with the previous eight, there are eight kinds of truth.
As for the eight kinds of speech where the object is false but the mind is true,
there is one who has truly not seen, but later forgets that he has not seen and gives rise to the thought that he has seen.
When asked by others if he has seen,
he answers, I have truly seen.
Although the object is false, because the mind is true, it is still called true speech.
The same applies to hearing, perceiving, and knowing.
It is further divided into four.
There is one who has truly seen, but later forgets this seeing and gives rise to the thought that he has not seen.
When asked by others if he has seen,
he answers, I have not seen.
Although it does not match the facts,
because the mind is true, it is still called true speech.
The same applies to hearing, perceiving, and knowing.
It is further divided into four.
Together with the previous, there are eight.
These previous sixteen
are the correct speech.
As for false speech,
the mind and object are both false,
there are eight kinds of speech.

There are also eight kinds of speech.
Therefore, in total there are sixteen kinds of speech.
As for the eight kinds of speech where both the object and mind are false,

When asked by others if they see,
they answer,
I really see.

This makes four.
